Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Planning Grant: Doubled Haploid Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
A new center is to be planned based at Iowa State University and University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign named the Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) for Doubled Haploid Research (CeDHR). CeDHR plans to provide the basic research foundation necessary for the applied research goals of industry and will make the process of Doubled Haploid line production both more effective and available in species where it is currently unavailable. The research scope, comprised of four primary areas, is unique among I/UCRCs: 1) Isolation of genes involved in the haploid induction and genome doubling process, 2) Establishment of a DH system in species, where it is not available yet, 3) Efficient screening procedures for haploids, and 4) A novel concept of an in vitro nursery including automation of this process and methods.

In order to meet the projected increase of global demand for food, feed, and fibre (100% by 2050), the efficiency, reliability, and speed of genetic improvement must be accelerated. The mission for the proposed Center will be to streamline and link the efforts of industry and academia towards speeding up plant breeding using doubled haploid (DH) through a formalized and extended research partnership. Students and postdoctoral researchers within the proposed Center will receive professional development training at both ISU and UIUC. In addition, industry representatives have indicated their need for scientists with multidisciplinary undergraduate or graduate training; a primary goal of the Center will be to address this critical training and educational need. Center trainees, including minorities and underrepresented groups, will be drawn from diverse backgrounds. Research findings will be disseminated internationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this planning grant was to hold a planning meeting for the proposed new Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC), the Competence Center for Doubled Haploid Research (CeDHR). The goals of the planning meeting were to (i) present a compelling case for the Center to prospective members, and (ii) determine the initial research agenda.

A strategic planning meeting was organized by the two universities involved, Iowa State University and University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, and held at Iowa State University, October 13-15, 2014. We contacted >50 companies/entities with potential interest in a CeDHR membership. 16 companies signed up for attending the planning meeting, two companies were not able to send a delegate with short notice (thus 14 companies attended in person). Additional 6 international companies got access to participate in the meeting online using Adobe Connect. Moreover, all presentations were recorded and made available to additional potantially interested companies after the planning meeting. In total 20 projects from both universities (either individually or collaborative projects) were presented to the participants either as oral or poster presentation. Even though the overall feedback was positive, and the research area deemed important by the participating companies, only three of the minimum six required letters of commitment to become future CeDHR members were obtained. Thus, a full proposal for a CeDHR was not prepared.

Primary reasons given by companies to not provide a letter of commitment, despite of general interest were: (1) economic downturn in agriculture for major crops starting in 2014 (still valid), (2) uncertainties due to upcoming mergers (such as between DuPont – Pioneer and Dow AgroSciences), (3) too broad range of crops – thus, species of interest may not be addressed within CeDHR, (4) preference for bilateral and more focused projects, and (5) for large companies ability to conduct respective research in house. This planning grant did help to discuss possible research projects, some of which have been formulated into proposals outside CeDHR, and some of those have been funded. However, the NSF I/UCRC framework did not appear the best fit for this research area at this time.
